title: The Best Zero Waste Vitamins & Sustainable Supplements
author: Nadine
description: Find the best zero waste vitamins and supplements available today, and why you should be making the switch!
cleaned_text: Getting all the important vitamins and minerals in your diet is critical to staying healthy. But it's more complicated than it seems to get all our nutrients from diet alone these days, especially if you have dietary restrictions or live a fast-paced lifestyle. This is where vitamin supplements come in handy, as they can help ensure we're getting everything we need to function optimally. But not all supplements are created equal. In fact, many traditional supplements come in single-use plastic packaging - obviously not the best choice if you care for the environment. If you're looking for a more sustainable way to get your essential vitamins and minerals, you'll want to opt for a zero waste multivitamin instead. In this article, we'll be discussing the best zero waste supplements on the market. We'll touch on what makes them sustainable, what nutrients they provide, and where you can find them. Keep reading to learn more about waste free vitamins! This article may contain compensated/affiliate links. See our full disclosure [here](https://zerowastememoirs.com/affiliate-disclosure/). Otherwise, jump straight into finding out which are the best supplement options on the market. These companies have made it their mission to create products that are not only good for your health but also good for the environment. But what's better, this company cares about the earth, too. The supplements come in biodegradable pouches to keep plastic waste out of landfills. Plus, for each pouch of supplements you purchase, HerbaLand plants a tree to help offset their carbon footprint. Why choose zero waste supplements? Currently, about [80% of Americans](https://www.crnusa.org/newsroom/crn-reveals-initial-data-2021-consumer-survey-dietary-supplements) consume vitamins and supplements. And while it's good that Americans are looking out for their health, the increased consumption brings with it an increase in packaging waste. Things like droppers, cotton balls, desiccants, tamper-evident seals, and dosage cups are all difficult or impossible to recycle, which is problematic for the environment. All this single-use plastic packaging often ends up in landfills or [polluting our oceans](https://zerowastememoirs.com/how-does-trash-get-in-the-ocean/). Currently, food packaging like vitamin bottles accounts for about [23% of the materials](https://www.epa.gov/sites/default/files/2015-08/documents/reducing_wasted_food_pkg_tool.pdf) that end up in landfills in the United States. That's almost a quarter of our trash! On top of that, the production of single-use food packages is damaging to the environment. [Each plastic bottle that's produced requires resources](https://foodprint.org/issues/the-environmental-impact-of-food-packaging/#:~:text=Each%20form%20of%20packaging%20uses,or%20sludge%20containing%20toxic%20contaminants.) like water, chemicals, petroleum, minerals, and energy. Using these resources can often generate the emissions of greenhouse gases and toxic waste that ends up in our water. Traditional packaging is often derived from ingredients that are not ethically sourced - for example, new plastic is created instead of recycled. Manufacturers often have little concern over the environmental impacts of the production of these materials. This means that buying multivitamins with traditional packaging can sometimes be an ethical nightmare. On the other hand, [zero-waste packaging](https://www.eesi.org/articles/view/the-problem-with-packaging-waste-how-zero-waste-grocers-are-powering-solutions) is made to be reused, recycled, or composted. This means that there is very little waste generated from the production of these products. Zero-waste packaging is often made from sustainable and ethical materials, like glass or aluminum. And since these materials can be recycled over and over again, they have a much smaller environmental impact than the virgin plastic most conventional vitamins are sold in. This type of packaging has a smaller carbon footprint, produces less pollution, and requires less resources to create. So, if you're looking for a way to be more sustainable, zero waste supplements are a great option! Supplements are a great way to make sure you're getting all the nutrients you need, but it's important to keep the planet in mind when you're choosing which ones to take. These brands offer eco-friendly, vegan options that will help you maintain your health without harming the earth.
